Based on your preferences, I would recommend the movie "The Giver" (1993). This film is set in a dystopian future where society has been completely stripped of individual freedom and choice. The protagonist, Jonas, lives in this society with no rights or freedoms for anyone living in it.
One of the main themes of this film is the importance of individual freedom and choice. Throughout the course of the film, Jonas undergoes a series of transformative experiences that allow him to gain access to an alternative reality where he has complete control over his own destiny.
Another important theme of this film is the importance of empathy and compassion in society.Throughout the course of the film, Jonas is forced to confront the harsh realities of life in the society described in the film. As a result of these experiences, Jonas begins to develop a greater sense of empathy and compassion towards the people living in the society described in the film.
Overall, "The Giver" (1993) is a thought-provoking dystopian movie that explores themes such as individual freedom and choice, empathy and compassion in society, and the importance of transformation and growth in life.

Based on the user's preference cues and genre suggestions, I would recommend 'The Last Samurai' and 'We Were Soldiers'.

'The Last Samurai' is a powerful and emotional film that explores themes of honor, loyalty, and sacrifice. The film stars Togo Igawa as Seppuku Kiyoi, who is tasked with committing ritual suicide known as seppuku. Alongside Igawa, the film also features Jsu Garcia as Takatada, Ralph Fiennes as Seppuku Kiyoi, Willem Dafoe as Tsunetoei, Judy Greer as Yutsumo, Chad Lindberg as Seppuku Kiyoi, Chad Lindberg 2. 'We Were Soldiers' is a gripping and emotional film that explores themes of bravery, sacrifice, teamwork, and leadership.

The film stars William Atherton as Private First Class Gary Smith, who is tasked with leading an elite group of American soldiers known as the "10th Mountain Division" (MTD) to rescue them from their Soviet prison camp known as "Chebokh" (CBK).

Other notable cast members include Jsu Garcia as Private First Class Gary Smith, Ralph Fiennes as Captain John F. Curry, and Willem Dafoe as General Westmoreland.

Based on user preferences, I would recommend "Red Cliff" (2008) directed by Zhang Yim. The movie is a two-part story set in China's Three Kingdoms period (220-280 A.D.). The first chapter follows the battle fought between General Liu Bei, his allies and the opposing army of Cao Cai, ruler of the state Luoyang. In this epic battle, Liu Bei emerges as the victorious leader, while Cao Cai is left to mourn his defeat.
The second chapter of "Red Cliff" explores Liu Bei's subsequent actions towards his newly acquired territory. The movie also examines the relationships between Liu Bei's allies and their respective states. Overall, "Red Cliff" is a highly entertaining epic battle movie that will appeal to fans of historical epics.
